content: The Act is titled the "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" and includes amendments related to anti-straw purchasing and firearms trafficking. The Act, titled the "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017," includes amendments related to anti-straw purchasing and firearms trafficking. Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to add a section on straw purchasing of firearms, making it unlawful for any person to knowingly purchase a firearm in interstate or foreign commerce. The Act prohibits the purchase of firearms in interstate or foreign commerce for another person, whether known or unknown, unless the recipient is a licensed importer, manufacturer, collector, or dealer. It also prohibits such transactions if the recipient is under indictment, convicted of a crime punishable by over a year in prison, a fugitive from justice, or an unlawful user of controlled substances. The Act prohibits the purchase of firearms for individuals who are mentally defective, committed to a mental institution, illegal aliens, dishonorably discharged from the Armed Forces, or former citizens of the United States. The Act prohibits the purchase of firearms for individuals who have renounced their US citizenship or are subject to a court order restraining them from harassing or threatening an intimate partner or child. The Act prohibits individuals convicted of domestic violence misdemeanors or those who pose a threat to their intimate partner or child from purchasing firearms. It also restricts individuals intending to use firearms for violent crimes or drug trafficking. The Act prohibits individuals from trafficking firearms or exporting them illegally. Violators face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or up to 25 years if the firearm is intended for a violent crime. Exceptions apply to lawfully purchased firearms. The Act prohibits trafficking in firearms, with penalties for violators. Exceptions apply to lawfully purchased firearms given as gifts or prizes in raffles, contests, or auctions. The Act prohibits trafficking in firearms, with penalties for violators who ship, transport, transfer, or receive 2 or more firearms in interstate or foreign commerce if they know or have reasonable cause to believe the recipient would violate federal law punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year. The Act prohibits trafficking in firearms, with penalties for violators including fines and imprisonment up to 25 years for those who commit the offense with 5 or more accomplices. Convicted individuals must forfeit any proceeds obtained from the violation. The Act imposes penalties for trafficking firearms, including fines and imprisonment up to 25 years for offenders with 5 or more accomplices. Convicted individuals must forfeit any proceeds obtained from the violation, including property used in the offense. The United States Code is amended to include sections 932 and 933 related to firearms trafficking and straw purchasing. The Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend guidelines for offenses under these sections. The Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend guidelines for offenses related to firearms trafficking and straw purchasing under sections 932 and 933 of title 18, United States Code. Penalties for individuals affiliated with gangs, cartels, or organized crime rings should be higher than for unaffiliated individuals. Amendments are made to the table of sections in chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code. Amendments are made to section 922(D) regarding straw purchasing of firearms, trafficking in firearms, and forfeiture and fines. Amendments to section 922(d) of title 18, United States Code include prohibiting the sale or disposal of firearms or ammunition to certain individuals and for criminal purposes. This subsection does not apply to licensed importers, manufacturers, dealers, or collectors. The subsection allows for the sale of firearms or ammunition to certain individuals who are not prohibited by law or have been granted relief from disabilities. Amendments to sections 924(a) and 924(h) of title 18, United States Code, increase penalties for knowingly violating subsections (d) or (g) of section 922, with fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to increase penalties for knowingly receiving or transferring firearms or ammunition for use in violent crimes or drug trafficking. Offenders face up to 25 years in prison, fines, or both. The amendment to Section 924 of title 18, United States Code increases penalties for receiving or transferring firearms for use in violent crimes or drug trafficking, with offenders facing up to 25 years in prison, fines, or both. This subsection will run concurrently with any term of imprisonment imposed on the person under section 932. SEC. 7. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(K) increases penalties for receiving or transferring firearms for use in violent crimes or drug trafficking, with offenders facing up to 25 years in prison, fines, or both. Section 924 of title 18, United States Code is amended to increase penalties for smuggling firearms or ammunition into the United States with intent to engage in illegal activities, punishable under various acts or state laws. Offenders could face up to 15 years in prison, fines, or both. The amendment to Section 924 of title 18, United States Code increases penalties for smuggling firearms or ammunition out of the United States with intent to engage in illegal activities. Offenders could face up to 15 years in prison, fines, or both.
